Award.AwardTitle: A Systems Approach to the Development and Function of C4 Photosynthesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Timothy Nelson (Yale University)

Co-PIs: Thomas Brutnell and Todd Mockler (Danforth Plant Science Center); Peng Liu (Iowa State University); Chris Myers, Robert Turgeon, Qi Sun, and Klaas van Wijk (Cornell University); and Joyce van Eck (Boyce Thompson Institute)

C4-type plants such as maize and several promising biofuel feedstocks have more efficient carbon-fixation, water and nitrogen use, and performance in high temperatures and light intensities, in comparison to C3-type plants such as rice and wheat. The traits conferring these C4 advantages are (1) cooperation of two distinct photosynthetic cell types (mesophyll and bundle sheath) for carbon fixation and photosynthesis, (2) enhanced movement of metabolites between cooperating cells, and (3) high density of leaf venation. These C4 traits are produced from genetic resources already present in less-efficient C3 plants, but regulated in more efficient patterns. Although C4 plants have evolved at least 50 times independently in various taxonomic groups, the molecular basis of the more efficient C4 regulatory system is insufficiently understood to extend its advantages to other crops and biofuel feedstocks.

A systems-level analysis of RNAs, proteins, metabolites, anatomy and physiology of corresponding developmental stages of maize (C4) and rice (C3) leaves has identified many of the molecular resources that produce the C4 traits. It has also revealed that additional corresponding data about small regulatory RNAs, epigenetic differences among cell types, protein modifications and several other "data channels" are needed to understand the production and regulation of these traits. In addition, more sophisticated computational approaches are needed to integrate the many "channels" of RNA, protein, anatomical and small molecule information that produce complex traits. This project will (1) obtain the missing data channels for C4 leaf developmental stages (2) utilize novel computational approaches for the integration of data channels and the modeling of regulatory networks that can be tested experimentally, and (3) test the regulatory basis for several C4 biochemical cellular traits by genetic and transgenic manipulation. This analysis will identify the regulatory points that are potential targets for the introduction of C4 traits in C3 species. Beyond producing a practical and profound understanding of C4 photosynthesis, the computational tools and systems resources developed by this project can be applied to other studies of plant development, biochemistry, physiology and productivity.

The impact of this project will be broadened through the novel BrachyBio! Outreach Program (http://bti.cornell.edu/brachybio), which introduces high school students to authentic plant genetics research, while providing the plant research community with a web-accessible collection of indexed mutant stocks of Brachypodium distachyon (C3) and Setaria viridis (C4). Project outcomes will be available through a project-specific public website (C3-C4DB, http://c3c4.tc.cornell.edu), and curated into the Gramene public database (http://www.gramene.org). Data will also be deposited at the NIH NCBI and the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI; www.ebi.ac.uk).

POR.DRECONTENT:
C4-type plants such as maize and several promising biofuel feedstocks possess a set of complex traits that greatly enhance their efficiency of carbon-fixation, water and nitrogen use, and performance in high temperatures and light intensities, in comparison to C3-type plants such as rice and many temperate grasses. The key C4 traits are (1) specialization and cooperation of two leaf photosynthetic cell types (mesophyll and bundle sheath) for carbon fixation and photosynthesis, (2) enhanced movement of metabolites between cooperating cells, and (3) high density of leaf venation. These C4 traits appear to be regulatory enhancements and diversifications of features already present in less-efficient C3 plants, but expressed under new cell-specific controls. Although C4 plants have evolved at least 50 times independently in various taxonomic groups, the molecular basis of key C4 traits is insufficiently understood to permit their introduction into important C3 crops to enhance their performance to manipulate existing networks in C4 crops or biofuel feedstocks.

 

In previous work we obtained layered channels of systems data along a calibrated leaf developmental gradient of maize (C4) and rice (C3)—transcriptomes, proteomes, metabolites, quantitative anatomy, and physiology. This provided a unique opportunity to turn this rich data into testable mechanistic models for the basis of C4 metabolism and for the development of its anatomical and regulatory infrastructure. In this project, we integrated and developed a variety of computational tools to discern the metabolic and developmental networks of genes, proteins, enzymatic activities, and metabolites that differentiate C4 from C3 biology. Using transgenic and other perturbations of these networks, we tested the predictions of the conceptual models and developed new models. During the project, we identified many genes and proteins with pivotal roles in the establishment of C4 metabolism and its supporting anatomy. These regulatory points and unique biochemistries are best targets for the introduction of C4 traits in C3 species.

 

Among the striking findings from this project are the following:

Two transcription factors, Scarecrow (SCR) and Shortroot (SHR) and their IDD gene partners pattern the development of the leaf bundle sheath and mesophyll cells that uniquely cooperate during C4 metabolism. We developed methods for finding the networks of the gene targets that these control.

 

The gas-impermeable barrier around the bundle sheath compartment created by the suberin biosynthetic pathway is at least partially dispensable to the function of the two-cell C4 metabolic cooperation. A leaky system may be sufficient to convert C3 species into more efficient C4-like function.

 

The activity of specific proteases (e.g., Clp system) and other post-translational modifications refine the cell-specific expression of C4 pathway components in bundle sheath and mesophyll cells both during development and at leaf maturity.

 

Modeling of the 2-cell C4 metabolism revealed that alterations in the cell-specificity of activity of a subset of pivotal enzymes are sufficient to shift the entire pathway between C3 and C4 versions.

 

The project produced many new computational tools for bioinformatics, statistics and modeling of genome-wide datasets that are generally applicable throughout biology research, all published and available to the public.

 

The impact of this project was broadened through the novel BrachyBio! Outreach Program (http://bti.cornell.edu/brachybio), which introduced high school students to authentic plant genetics research, while providing the plant research community with a web-accessible collection of indexed mutant stocks of Brachypodium distachyon (C3) and Setaria viridis (C4). This fulfills a stated mission of the NSF: to communicate the significance of the outcomes of plant genome research to society.

 

The project outcomes have been curated into the Gramene public database (http://www.gramene.org), and datasets and models/algorithms have been deposited into the public repositories appropriate for each data type: Github for gene network and metabolic models and software, SRA (NCBI) for RNAseq data, ProteomeXchange/PRIDE and Massive for proteomic data, and Github for statistical  packages. The peer-reviewed project publications provide links to the correct data accessions at each repository.
